texts.definition: An activity requiring players to time their actions in relation to a rhythm.
markups: <style="Definition">An activity requiring players to time their actions in relation to a rhythm.</style>

Real-time games require players to act due to events that occur in the game. When these required actions occur in rhythm, they force players to perform <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style>, where the timing and stability over time can be just as important as performing the right action.

Early sports games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Olympic%20Decathlon">Olympic Decathlon</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Summer%20Games">Summer Games</link></style> primarily stimulated <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Sports">Sports</link></style> by requiring players to perform long sequences of <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style>, and the outcome was judged upon how well the players kept the rhythm.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/PaRappa%20the%20Rapper">PaRappa the Rapper</link></style> require players to hit various buttons in certain combinations while following certain rhythms, and eases gameplay by having music or songs that have the same rhythm the players must follow. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Donkey%20Konga">Donkey Konga</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Rock%20Band%20series">Rock Band series</link></style> does the same but provide specialized instrument-like game controls; the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dance%20Dance%20Revolution%20series">Dance Dance Revolution series</link></style> similarly provides a dance mat to make players dance to play.

The fantasy game series <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon's%20Lair%20series">Dragon's Lair</link></style>, the thriller <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Heavy%20Rain">Heavy Rain</link></style>, and the 2013 version in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tomb%20Raider%20series">Tomb Raider series</link></style> require players to press certain sequences of buttons correctly to successfully complete some action events in the games.

<style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> is a way to require players to perform individual actions in <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, e.g. avoiding <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="moveable-tiles">Moveable Tiles</link></style> or avoiding <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style> goals. The actions themselves typically are simple ones, such as button presses, and the design of the pattern mainly consist of deciding with combinations and what <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> is required. Since they are self-contained the difficulty of these actions can be set with quite high level of precision, and this makes <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> good candidates for <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> and through this <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, especially since they are quite unproblematic to run user tests on.

Two main sub-varieties of <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> exist. <style="Link"><link="quick-time-events">Quick Time Events</link></style> are a form of <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> used to create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mini%20Games">Mini Games</link></style> in other games (found for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Heavy%20Rain">Heavy Rain</link></style>), either to provide <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> or to provide <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>. The other consists of equipping players with <style="Link"><link="mimetic-interfaces">Mimetic Interfaces</link></style> so that their actions while gaming are similar to play an instrument or dancing.

The reasons for performing <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> can simply be to <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style>, which may have a direct diegetic explanation (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon's%20Lair%20series">Dragon's Lair</link></style>) or not (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dance%20Dance%20Revolution%20series">Dance Dance Revolution series</link></style>). In other cases they are to achieve <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> - and when these <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> are the only way to beat <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> this adds the reason of achieving <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> goals for performing the <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style>.
Having <style="Link"><link="clickability">Clickability</link></style> in a game is a way of letting players have the option to engage in their own <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style>.

While <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> can be explained as copies of other activities through <style="Link"><link="mimetic-interfaces">Mimetic Interfaces</link></style> in some games (e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Rock%20Band%20series">Rock Band series</link></style>), in others they are mapped to <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon's%20Lair%20series">Dragon's Lair</link></style>). Failing the later, especially when the <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> are linked to <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style> goals, can diegetically be represented as triggering deadly  <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>. However, some <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> are constructed as repeating events that instead require <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> to navigate. This means that both patterns can modulate each other.

Unless used to avoid actual <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> in a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>, players need some way of knowing what <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> they need to do in the immediate future. This is most often done through <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style> which at the same time provide <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> are <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style> performed with the intentions of achieving temporal <style="Link"><link="configuration">Configuration</link></style> goals in <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>. As such they can create <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style> and are also examples of <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> which may be important to gain <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> of a game. The motivation for the <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> often comes from games where <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Show%20Must%20Go%20On">The Show Must Go On</link></style>, and the players are either supposed to follow the rhythm of an <style="Link"><link="agents">Agent</link></style> giving mentorship or to avoid dangers in the world - typically <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style> since players need to be aware of what they should do next. This, and that they create <style="Link"><link="repetitive-gameplay">Repetitive Gameplay</link></style>, either in tempo or in type of action, make it possible for players performing <style="CurrentLink">Rhythm-Based Actions</style> to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sensory-Motoric%20Engrossment">Sensory-Motoric Engrossment</link></style>.
